descendants.content:
@nutmeg

Meaningfully tho, how would they?

@compost

descendants.content:
@JimmyB @nutmeg

It is our habits that make us or break us.

Some of our habits have created this crisis and we will have to change those.

Solving the crisis implies for us to change.

account.note:

fields.name: Compost blog
fields.value: https://paper.wf/compost/

fields.name: Compost group
fields.value: @compost@a.gup.pe

descendants.content:
@compost

Our habits have abeen very deliberately fuelled. And we cannot change that without changing the source. I can take more trains (I do in fact). But that changes nothing. Even if everyone took more trains, it would have almost zero impact. the changes needed are so much bigger.

What it does do if I change my habits is to help me to see the issue clearly. But I cannot mistake my personal lifestyle efforts with actual impact. Impact actions have to be at a different level

@nutmeg

descendants.content:
@JimmyB @nutmeg

This is where most people don't see the importance of their actions daily.

Oh, I am not that bad and my neighbor does worse.

If we start by taking accountability for our actions we will get a lot done.

descendants.content:
@compost

No - that's not what I'm saying. It's got nothing to do with whether I am better or worse than my neighbour. It's whether I am putting my energy into where it really counts. Like engaging politically. That might make a difference...

I will recycle, compost, fly (a lot) less, drive less etc etc. But I am kidding myself if I think that these actions are meaningful - even if engaged with by large numbers - while the corporate polluters run unchecked.

@nutmeg

descendants.content:
@nutmeg

The focus on guilting individuals about their behaviours is a useful distraction from us focusing on the folks who can actually do something. Good example is all the recycling we do. I's utterly meaningless while AI expansion is booming the way it is.

I could go on. I think that personal involvement in addressing the climate crisis is only useful in so far as it engages individuals in the issue.

Meaningful action means taking down microsoft, twitter, amazon, Exxon - etc

@compost

descendants.content:
@JimmyB @nutmeg

It is through habits that we can do something and this means all of us.

If every human being woke up in the morning saying themselves:
- what can I do today for the climate?
- what can I change with my habits to improve the climate?

The planet would be in a better shape.

descendants.content:
@compost

I agree completely! That would change it! However, they won't and folks like the idiot who won't engage with reality - which also means finding those actions which will actually save us, rather than ranting at and blocking allies - is what's required. I do everything I can. Including some very expensive personal choices. But I am not kidding myself that they are anything more than self indulgence and conscience salving.

They are not effective solutions to the crisis.

@nutmeg

descendants.content:
@JimmyB @nutmeg

Every day I took on myself to do a daily post to try to inspire people to reflect on their habits. Because composting is a habit that can make a difference.

I know that I am just a drop in the ocean, but I do not care about that or what other people do wrong for I am not the judge.

We have to focus on what we can change at our level.
